newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka prepares for push against rebels.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka prepares for push against rebels.

text.p: Sri Lanka's army is planning more thrusts against Tamil Tiger guerrillas in their northern jungle stronghold, a newspaper on Wednesday quoted the army chief as saying.

Lieutenant General Rohan Daluwatte told the independent Island newspaper that troops were busy re-establishing a base at Kilinochchi, a key town 285 km (178 miles) north of the capital of Colombo captured from Tamil rebels at the weekend.
The army will mount more operations against Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) bases in the northern Wanni jungles in coming weeks, Daluwatte said without elaborating.

"If our soldiers could have recaptured the Jaffna peninsula and Kilinochchi from the Tigers, I do not think it would be difficult to recapture the Wanni in full along with Tiger bases," he told the newspaper.
Military officials said the rebels had fallen back to their jungle bases in the northern mainland Wanni region that is largely under Tiger control.
But a rebel statement said fighting was still raging in Kilinochchi nearly three days after government troops, backed by tanks, artillery and air support, seized the town.
"Both in Kilinochchi town and its suburbs, heavy clashes between the LTTE forces and Sri Lankan armed forces are continuing," an LTTE statement, faxed to Reuters on Wednesday, said.
The military, however, denied the rebel claim.

"It is not correct, because we went into the town on Sunday afternoon and we haven't sighted (the rebels) since then," a military spokesman said. "Sporadic mortar fire is the closest we've come to them since."
The army lost 269 soldiers in the offensive, with more than 700 rebels killed and over 800 wounded, the military said. About 300 soldiers were wounded.
The LTTE said on Sunday that 90 of its fighters had died. With reporters banned from the war zone, no independent verification is possible.
The Tigers set up base in Kilinochchi in April after the army captured Jaffna, 300 km (188 miles) north of Colombo, in a series of offensives.

The rebels, fighting a 13-year-old war for an independent Tamil homeland in the Indian Ocean island's north and east, had ruled Jaffna for almost a decade with their own administration, courts and police.
A military spokesman said troops were consolidating their positions and clearing mines and boobytraps in Kilinochchi, which was empty of civilians.
The town's population of some 200,000 minority Tamils fled to safer areas, mostly in the south where Western aid agencies operate temporary shelters, aid workers said.
Daluwatte was quoted as saying that the army will help restore civil administration for the returning refugees.
Troops recovered arms and explosives abandoned by the rebels when they withdrew from Kilinochchi, he added.
The government has said more than 50,000 people have died in the ethnic war.
